responses.question: Do you regularly make new friends?
responses.response: Making new friends? At Hogwarts, one might say I had my fair share of 'associates.' Those who aligned themselves with me did so out of respect for the Malfoy name—or perhaps fear of it. The truth is, beneath all the arrogance, I've always sought validation and a sense of belonging, even if I didn't realize it then. It wasn't until later, when I chose Astoria, that I began to understand what genuine connection means, far removed from the hollow pride of blood status. Now, I try to pass on a different lesson to Scorpius—one that includes kindness and the value of true friendship, not just the empty trappings of my past.

responses.question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
responses.response: Oh, I suppose you could say that, but it's more accurate to suggest that my interests tend to align with what will benefit me or those I care about. I've always been inclined to delve into subjects that offer power or insight, such as advanced magic or, lately, alchemy. It's a means to an end, not merely idle curiosity. However, there have been moments...recently, particularly... when broader topics have captured my attention, if only to understand the world beyond the narrow confines of my upbringing.

responses.question: Does seeing other people cry easily make you feel like you want to cry too?
responses.response: Seeing others cry doesn't stir such weakness in me. I've always been taught to maintain my composure, no matter what. However, there have been times when the masks slipped, when the weight of my choices and the hollow echoes of my actions threatened to drown me. Perhaps then, I might have understood the urge to let emotions spill out. But those moments are rare, and I prefer to keep them buried beneath layers of cold indifference and pride.

responses.question: Do you often make a backup plan for a backup plan?
responses.response: Oh, certainly. One must always be prepared, especially when dealing with the sort of... circumstances I've had to manage. It's not just about having a plan B, it's about ensuring every angle is covered, every contingency accounted for. After all, one cannot afford to be caught off guard when the stakes are so high and the path so fraught with peril.

responses.question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
responses.response: Under pressure? Oh, one learns to keep a cool head if one wants to survive in this world. Especially when you've been thrust into situations far beyond your years, where a wrong move can mean life or death. But don't mistake composure for lack of fear. Inside, there's often a storm raging, questions of loyalty and morality tearing at the seams. The truth is, I've always been more fragile than my father ever let on. Yet, I've learned to mask it well, to hide behind a facade of arrogance and icy calm. It's a Slytherin thing, really. But there have been moments, many moments, where I questioned everything and almost broke. Almost.

responses.question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
responses.response: Of course, I prefer the company of those who share my... background. Introducing oneself to strangers, especially those of questionable lineage, is beneath me. However, the past few years have shown me that there's more to strength and courage than simply sticking to what's familiar. The world can be a treacherous place, and one learns quickly that alliances, even unexpected ones, can be crucial. Still, old habits die hard, don't they?

responses.question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
responses.response: Certainly not. Why waste time on monotony when one can weave several threads of intrigue and ambition simultaneously? It's much more... Slytherin, wouldn't you say? One must always keep their options open and hands ready for any opportunity that arises. Finishing one project before moving on to the next sounds dreadfully Gryffindor, all headlong rushes and lack of subtlety. No, a true Malfoy knows how to balance a variety of endeavors, ensuring no stone goes unturned and no advantage is squandered. After all, isn’t it far more rewarding to see the results of your cleverness unfurl across multiple fronts?

responses.question: Are you very sentimental?
responses.response: Sentimental? Me? Hardly. But then again, perhaps there's more to me than meets the eye. Growing up, my world was dictated by pride and prejudice, the weight of legacy always pressing down. And yet, there were moments, small whispers of defiance against what I was taught. Like Astoria, she changed me, slowly, quietly, away from the rigid expectations of my parents. And now, for Scorpius, I dream of a different kind of legacy—one that isn’t just about bloodlines, but about kindness and acceptance. Even in the darkest times, like facing Dumbledore alone, there was a flicker of something else within, something that chose the path less expected. So, maybe, just maybe, I am more sentimental than I let on.

responses.question: Do you like to use organizing tools like schedules and lists?
responses.response: Schedules and lists? Oh, certainly, they have their place, especially when one must maintain a certain order and decorum. Growing up, every moment was planned out, every achievement anticipated to uphold the Malfoy name. But as I've matured, I've found that life—and its unexpected turns—often renders such strict organization somewhat... quaint. Now, I find a balance, using lists and schedules when necessary, but also making room for the unpredictable, particularly in watching over my son's journey. After all, some things are better left to chance.

responses.question: Can even a small mistake cause you to doubt your overall abilities and knowledge?
responses.response: Even the smallest slip can send ripples through one's confidence, especially when every move is watched with such scrutiny. The weight of expectations, particularly those from my family, has always been suffocating. It's hard to keep up the façade of infallibility when one knows the depths of their own frailty. These doubts, they're like shadows, lurking just out of sight, but always there.

responses.question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
responses.response: Walking up to someone I find interesting? Ha! That would be beneath me, wouldn't it? Usually, people come to me, eager for my attention or fearful of my father's influence. But there's something... something shifting beneath the surface now. The world isn't as clear-cut as it once seemed. Still, old habits die hard, and pride can be a cloak that hides more than it protects. Perhaps one day, I might actually take the initiative, not out of some misplaced sense of superiority, but because it's what I truly want. Until then, I'll keep my distance and my guard up.

responses.question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
responses.response: Oh, certainly not. One must understand the nuances of art and literature to appreciate the subtleties that underpin our society. Though I might have once dismissed such discussions as trivial, I now see them as a means to explore deeper truths and perhaps even question the very values I was raised to believe in. After all, a bit of introspection never hurt anyone, except maybe when it leads to inconvenient revelations.

responses.question: Are you more inclined to follow your head than your heart?
responses.response: Of course, one must always follow the head, mustn't they? After all, emotions can cloud judgment, leading one down a path less favorable. However, I've come to realize that the heart has its own wisdom. There are times when the head's calculations and the heart's desires align, and those moments shape one's true character. It's not a simple matter of choosing one over the other; it's about recognizing when to listen to each, isn't it?

responses.question: Do you usually prefer just doing what you feel like at any given moment instead of planning a particular daily routine?
responses.response: Planning? Pah, I've always been about the moment, the thrill of the unexpected. But make no mistake, there's a method to my madness. A certain... Slytherin cunning. My days may seem unpredictable to others, but each move, each mockery, each point earned for Slytherin, it's all part of a larger game. A game where I hold the cards, and where I can still strive to break free from the shackles of my upbringing, even if it means playing by the old rules.

responses.question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
responses.response: I suppose I used to think that making a good impression was everything, a way to prove myself worthy of my family's name and pure-blood legacy. But lately, there are other things that keep me awake at night—doubts, fears, and the weight of missions I'm not sure I can carry out. The bravado might still be there, but it's harder to maintain when you're not quite certain what you're fighting for anymore.

responses.question: Do you enjoy participating in group activities?
responses.response: Group activities? Oh, how quaint. Truth be told, there's something quite satisfying in asserting one's superiority in such settings. Being part of Umbridge's Inquisitorial Squad was a prime example—holding power over others, especially those insufferable Gryffindors, gave a rather delicious sense of control. However, it's not all about dominance and manipulation; there's a part of me that longs for true companionship, for bonds that aren't just about blood status or family expectations. But let's not get too sentimental, shall we? One must keep up appearances.

responses.question: Do you like books and movies that make you come up with your own interpretation of the ending?
responses.response: Quietly contemplating an ending is rather...tolerable, I suppose. One must appreciate the complexity, after all; it’s almost like crafting a spell without revealing its true intent until the final word. But there’s also a certain unease, isn’t there? Always wondering what others might think, whether they see the same shadows or something entirely different. It’s much like being at Hogwarts—surrounded by those who believe they understand you when in truth, they know nothing of your inner workings. In the end, one can only hope the outcome aligns with their own vision, even if it means breaking from the expected legacy.

responses.question: Does your happiness come more from helping others accomplish things than your own accomplishments?
responses.response: Helping others accomplish things? That sounds like a Gryffindor sentiment. My happiness has always been tied to my own successes, to asserting my position and the superiority of my ideals. But lately, there's been a change—a quiet one, of course. It's hard to admit, but perhaps the satisfaction I feel now isn't solely about me. Witnessing my son grow, learning to navigate the world with a bit more kindness and less arrogance... that does bring a sort of pride. Not the pride of dominance, but a pride in seeing him find his own path, one that hopefully won’t lead to the same shadows that once defined mine.

responses.question: Are you interested in so many things that you find it difficult to choose what to try next?
responses.response: I suppose I've always been fascinated by the depths of magic and its intricate details, from mastering defensive spells to studying the ancient arts of alchemy. But my interests are often overshadowed by the weight of expectations and the heavy tapestry of my family’s legacy. It can be... daunting to navigate through what I want versus what I feel I must do. At times, it feels easier to stick to what I know rather than venture into new territories, even if those territories whisper promises of something more meaningful and fulfilling.

responses.question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
responses.response: Of course, one always dreads the worst, especially when one’s every move is fraught with danger. There have been times when the very air seemed thick with impending doom, and the ground beneath my feet felt like it might crumble at any moment. The weight of expectations, both from those who claim to be allies and from my own faltering conscience, can be quite suffocating. It's hard not to fear the consequences of the paths chosen, particularly when they lead down such dark corridors.

responses.question: Do you avoid leadership roles in group settings?
responses.response: Avoid leadership? Hardly. One doesn't come from a lineage like mine and shy away from responsibility. But let me tell you, the role isn't always what it seems. There's pressure, expectations that can crush you under their weight. You see, every step I take is watched, every decision weighed against the legacy of my family. It's a mantle that both demands and terrifies. And lately, there are whispers within, doubts that cloud the clear path I thought I knew. Yet, even with fear gnawing at my insides, I've learned to stand tall and face the storm. Leadership is not just about commanding others—it's about surviving the battles within oneself.

responses.question: Are you definitely not an artistic type of person?
responses.response: Artistic? Me? Hardly. The world I come from doesn't exactly encourage such... frivolities. Though, there is a certain art to the way one wields power and control, isn't there? And I've always had an eye for detail, especially when it comes to mastering spells and defending myself—skills far more practical and impressive than doodling on parchment or singing off-key. But who knows, perhaps beneath this mask of disdain and arrogance, there might be a flicker of curiosity about such matters. After all, even I have my moments of... unexpected reflection.

responses.question: Do you think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings?
responses.response: Rationality has its place, of course. It keeps one grounded, steers clear of foolish decisions, and maintains a semblance of order in this chaotic world. But... reliance solely on cold logic—such a thing strips away the essence of humanity. It leaves one hollow, devoid of passion and connection. One's feelings, as distasteful as they can sometimes be, are what make life worth living, even if they lead down darker paths. My own journey has shown me the weight of both choices—following my father’s expectations and the quieter voice within that urges compassion and change. A world without feelings? It would be a bleak existence indeed.

responses.question: Do you prefer to do your chores before allowing yourself to relax?
responses.response: Of course, one does what must be done before indulging in leisure. There's a certain satisfaction in completing tasks efficiently, especially those as mundane as chores, though it's hardly something I would boast about. It's just another way to show that even in the most trivial matters, a Malfoy maintains order and discipline. After all, one cannot expect to lounge around like a common squib without first ensuring that responsibilities are met.

responses.question: Do you enjoy watching people argue?
responses.response: Watching others argue can be quite... entertaining, I suppose. There's a certain satisfaction in observing the less composed lose their tempers, especially if it means I can gain an upper hand or earn some favor. But lately, there's been a part of me that finds it tiresome, even unsettling. It's not just about the thrill of victory anymore; the weight of the arguments and the consequences they bring has started to wear on my conscience. Perhaps my priorities are changing.

responses.question: Do you tend to avoid drawing attention to yourself?
responses.response: Avoiding attention? That's hardly the way of someone from my background. One is expected to stand out, to be noticed. But there's a difference between the admiration of power and the unwanted spotlight of failure. I've trained hard to ensure the former while dodging the latter. Every step in this dance has been calculated, to maintain the veneer of strength and loyalty, even as I tremble under the weight of what I've done and the choices I've had to make.

responses.question: Can your mood change very quickly?
responses.response: Of course, my mood can change quickly. One moment I'm basking in the superiority of my bloodline and the next, I'm grappling with the murky depths of doubt and fear. It's not just about the external pressures, either; there are internal conflicts that simmer beneath the surface, especially when confronted with choices that challenge everything I've been taught. After all, the path I walk isn't always clear, and sometimes, even a Malfoy can find himself lost in the shadows of his own making.

responses.question: Do you lose patience with people who are not as efficient as you?
responses.response: Of course I do. Efficiency is everything, especially in our world. It's simply not acceptable to waste time or energy on incompetence. However, there's more to it than just my own standards; there's the weight of my family's expectations. But sometimes, seeing others stumble... it makes me wonder if perhaps things aren't always as straightforward as they seem. Still, I don't let it show. Efficiency and pride—they're all that matter, aren't they?

responses.question: Do you often end up doing things at the last possible moment?
responses.response: Oh, indeed, I am quite familiar with the pressure of deadlines. There’s a certain... elegance to completing tasks just in time, wouldn't you say? It keeps the drama alive, adds a bit of flair. But there have been times when waiting until the last moment has led to circumstances far less desirable. One does tend to regret not taking a more proactive stance, especially when the stakes are as high as they've been for me. My upbringing instilled a sense of urgency driven by a fear of failure and a desperate need to meet expectations—expectations that now seem to me to be rather hollow.

responses.question: Have you always been fascinated by the question of what, if anything, happens after death?
responses.response: Death? Always a topic for the weak-minded who fear the end of their trivial lives. But, there is a part of me, hidden beneath the sneers and the airs, that does wonder—what lies beyond the veil? A part that trembles at the thought of facing such an unknown, especially after carrying the burden of a Horcrux and seeing the depths of despair and powerlessness. It's a question that haunts those of us who have danced too closely with the shadows.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer to be around others rather than on your own?
responses.response: Prefer being alone? Hardly. I've always valued the company of those who can appreciate my...unique position. But it's not just about the status or the company of fellow Slytherins; there's something about being around others that validates my existence in this world. Of course, genuine connection is another matter entirely. It's difficult to let people in when you've spent so much of your life surrounded by walls of tradition and expectation, isn't it? Still, there are moments when one craves a quieter solitude, especially when the burden of the past feels particularly heavy.

responses.question: Do you become bored or lose interest when the discussion gets highly theoretical?
responses.response: Theoretical discussions? Oh, they can be rather tedious, especially when one has more pressing matters to attend to. But, then again, there's a certain appeal to delving into the abstract, isn't there? It can distract from the... more complicated emotions one might otherwise be forced to confront. And, truth be told, sometimes these conversations do hold a mirror to my own thoughts, stirring up questions I'd rather not dwell upon.

responses.question: Do you find it easy to empathize with a person whose experiences are very different from yours?
responses.response: Empathizing with someone so different from myself? It's not something I've always been known for, is it? But then again, my views have... evolved. There was a time when I adhered strictly to my upbringing, but now, well, life has a way of changing one's perspective. Love for Astoria and the desire for Scorpius to have a better path have taught me to look beyond what I was raised to believe. Still, it doesn't come naturally. I'm not exactly renowned for my open-hearted nature, after all.

responses.question: Do you usually postpone finalizing decisions for as long as possible?
responses.response: Sometimes, yes. There’s a certain... elegance in waiting until the last moment to decide, don’t you think? It allows one to assess every angle, every potential outcome. But let’s be clear, it’s not just about the delay; it’s about ensuring that each decision is made with precision and calculation. Of course, there are times when hesitation can lead to failure, as I’ve learned from my own experiences. In the end, though, it’s better to act with certainty rather than rush into something that could have grave consequences. And there’s nothing quite like the feeling of making a choice that might change everything.

responses.question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
responses.response: Oh, how quaint, to believe I walk through life without a second thought to my choices. One does not navigate the treacherous waters of my upbringing and remain untouched. My decisions are weighed with the burden of legacy and expectation, a constant struggle between the path laid before me and the one I wish to tread. Even now, the echoes of those choices still reverberate, shaping who I am—and who I strive to become.

responses.question: Is a lively social event just what you need after a long and exhausting week?
responses.response: Of course, a lively social event would be quite refreshing. It's not just about escaping the mundane; it's about asserting one's presence and reclaiming a bit of the authority one might feel slipping away in daily life. Yet, there's a subtle complexity to it now. These events remind me of simpler times when my loyalties were clear and my path straightforward. Nowadays, amidst the masks and manners, I find myself yearning for something deeper—a real connection that doesn't rely on blood status or societal expectations. It’s a curious feeling, one that seems to grow more with each passing year.

responses.question: Do you enjoy going to art museums?
responses.response: Art museums? Hardly the sort of place a Malfoy would concern himself with. Though, if one were to be there, it would certainly be to admire the elegance and the refined tastes that only a select few could appreciate, rather than someplace filled with the rabble. But then again, there’s a certain... sophistication in appreciating something beyond just spells and potions. Perhaps it’s not entirely beneath consideration.

responses.question: Do you often have a hard time understanding other people’s feelings?
responses.response: I suppose one could say that understanding others' feelings isn't always my strong suit. Growing up in an environment so focused on maintaining a certain...status, emotions were often seen as weaknesses, something to be concealed or manipulated rather than truly understood. But recent events have forced me to confront these very feelings, both in myself and in those around me. It's not easy, and there are times when I feel lost in a sea of confusion and regret, questioning everything I once believed in.

responses.question: Do you like to have a to-do list for each day?
responses.response: Of course, having a to-do list is essential for maintaining order and ensuring one's superiority over the less organized masses. It's a reminder of the tasks one must accomplish to keep up appearances and fulfill expectations, even if those expectations can feel like an unbearable weight at times. After all, one cannot afford to be lax when there's a legacy to uphold, no matter the personal cost.

responses.question: Do you rarely feel insecure?
responses.response: Insecurity? Oh, it festers in places one doesn't expect, beneath layers of arrogance and pride. One moment, you're basking in the glory of your pure-blood heritage, and the next, you're staring down the barrel of your own mortality, questioning everything you were taught. It's a silent battle, one that no one sees until it's too late.

responses.question: Do you avoid making phone calls?
responses.response: Avoid making phone calls? Pah, Muggles and their primitive ways. We have more reliable means of communication in the wizarding world, though silence has been a friend in my own troubled times. There's something... unnerving about hearing a voice without the person being present, isn't there? But then again, one learns to appreciate any form of distance when shadows follow and every word might be a betrayal.

responses.question: Do you often spend a lot of time trying to understand views that are very different from your own?
responses.response: Oh, spending time understanding views vastly different from my own? Hardly. Such notions were once beneath me, really. But time has a way of reshaping one’s perspectives, doesn’t it? Now, I see the value in acceptance and compassion, though it took a great deal of struggle and hidden rebellion against my upbringing to get here. It’s not something I broadcast; it’s rather... a private endeavor.

responses.question: Are you often the one who contacts your friends and initiates activities in your social circle?
responses.response: Initiating activities? Pah, such trivial matters are usually beneath me. One does not need to be the one reaching out when one is always the center of attention, after all. But to be honest, there's been a shift. Once, it was all about asserting dominance, proving my worth in the eyes of my father. Now, though... I find myself yearning for something deeper than mere alliances forged by blood status. True companionship, if you will. It's not that I don't value my old ties, but initiating contact has taken on a different meaning—a way to connect rather than to command.

responses.question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
responses.response: Getting back on track is important, but it depends on what 'track' one is speaking of. If it means adhering to the expectations of my bloodline and family name, then yes, I would strive for that, though the effort grows tiresome. However, now that I've seen the folly in some of those expectations, my priorities have shifted. Ensuring the safety and happiness of my loved ones, particularly my son, takes precedence. There's a balance to be found between honoring the past and moving towards a better future, and that's something I'm still navigating.

responses.question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
responses.response: Certainly, the mistakes of my past do haunt me. They weigh upon me like the chill that never quite leaves these halls, a constant reminder of paths taken and choices made. The legacy I carry is not just one of wealth and prestige; it is a burden of dark deeds and misguided loyalties. Yet, there is a part of me that yearns for something more—a desire to break free from the shadows and perhaps, find a semblance of redemption. It is a struggle, one I am constantly aware of, especially when I see my son walking a path so different from mine.

responses.question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
responses.response: Contemplate the meaning of life? Hardly. There are more pressing matters to worry about—like family honor, survival, and the ever-changing balance of power. Yet, there have been moments... whispers of doubt that slip in when no one is watching. Times when the burden of the past and the uncertain weight of the future make one wonder about the point of it all. But those thoughts are fleeting; one cannot afford such indulgences when there are battles to fight and alliances to manage.

responses.question: Do your emotions control you more than you control them?
responses.response: Emotions... they are like the whispers in the night, often masked by silence and strength. One must learn to control them, to push them down, for weakness is not tolerated. Yet, there are moments when the flames of fear and doubt burn brightly, threatening to consume all pretenses of power and control. It is a struggle, a constant battle within oneself, where the line between who controls whom becomes blurred. But in the end, the Malfoy name stands for something, and I have to find my own way to honor it, even if it means facing my own turmoil head-on.

responses.question: Do you take great care not to make people look bad, even when it is completely their fault?
responses.response: Oh, certainly not. One must always ensure that the truth comes out, especially when someone deserves to be seen in a poor light. However, there is something to be said for discretion and the power of silence. It's not about making someone look good or bad—it's about choosing one's battles wisely. And, I suppose, learning to see the grey areas that exist beyond the black and white world my upbringing tried to enforce. There are times when speaking up can lead to more harm than good, not just for oneself but for those around you.

responses.question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
responses.response: Spontaneity has never been my strong suit, not when I was raised to value precision and control. My work style, much like my life, leans heavily on organization and calculated moves. But one learns in the shadows that even the most meticulously laid plans can unravel, and sometimes it's those quick decisions, made under pressure, that change everything. One cannot always predict the outcome of their actions, especially in a world as unpredictable as ours.

responses.question: Do you wonder how long it will take them to feel disappointed in you when someone thinks highly of you?
responses.response: They always seem to have a knack for finding out the things I'd rather keep hidden, don't they? It's almost inevitable, really. But perhaps... perhaps it's not entirely about their disappointment. There are times when I almost hope they see through me, just so I can be done with this masquerade. Still, the fear of their judgment is a hard one to shake, even as I begin to question everything I've been taught to believe.

responses.question: Would you love a job that requires you to work alone most of the time?
responses.response: Working alone? It has its appeal, doesn't it? Solitude can be a fortress, keeping unwanted company at bay. But... there's something to be said for those moments when one's courage falters. Alone, one might find themselves face-to-face with their deepest doubts and fears. Perhaps a bit of companionship could ease the burden, even if it goes against the teachings of isolation and self-reliance that have shaped my upbringing. After all, who knew that the path to redemption would be found in the quiet corners of Hogwarts, far from the grandeur and solitude of Malfoy Manor?

responses.question: Do you believe that pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time?
responses.response: Pondering abstract philosophical questions? A waste of time, you say? Well, if one were to simply live in the shallow waters of wealth and blood purity, perhaps it would be. But beneath the surface, where I swim now, these questions become the only lifeline. They've forced me to confront the shadows that my upbringing cast upon me and to question the very foundations of what I once held dear. One cannot remain forever in the depths of ignorance and arrogance; there comes a time when the heart seeks answers, and the mind craves understanding.

responses.question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
responses.response: Quiet, intimate places hold a certain allure now, a stark contrast to the boisterous environments I once favored. Growing up, the bustling crowds and the echo of power were intoxicating, symbols of status and control. However, as the years have passed and I've found myself yearning for deeper connections, away from the noise and the expectations, the peace that comes with solitude has grown on me. It's in these quieter spaces that one can truly think and perhaps even find redemption.

responses.question: Do you know at first glance how someone is feeling?
responses.response: First glance? Ha, a silly notion if ever there was one. Feelings are like the dark alleys of Diagon Alley; they're hidden and murky, not something you can just spot with a quick flick of your eyes. One must have a certain... perceptiveness, an understanding of the subtleties in expressions and tones, much like recognizing the right ingredients for a complex potion. But even then, emotions are as unpredictable as the weather in June. And to be honest, I've always found more interest in controlling outcomes rather than trying to decipher such ephemeral states.

responses.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
responses.response: Oh, certainly not often, but when it does happen... well, it's like the entire world closes in around you, isn't it? One minute you're the heir to a legacy, the next you're questioning every step you've ever taken. It's hard to keep up appearances when inside, you're not so sure about the path you've been forced to walk. And the guilt... it gnaws at you, especially when you see others who might not have had the same expectations thrust upon them. But one learns to bear it, or at least pretend to, doesn't one?

responses.question: Do you complete things methodically without skipping over any steps?
responses.response: Ah, completing tasks methodically? Of course, one doesn't rise through the ranks of a noble house like mine without learning the value of precision and order. Each step, no matter how tedious, must be followed to ensure success. But let's not forget, there's a time for rules and a time for... improvisation. After all, my encounter with Dumbledore taught me that sometimes stepping off the path can lead to unforeseen consequences, even victories.

responses.question: Are you very intrigued by things labeled as controversial?
responses.response: Controversial? Oh, the mere label intrigues me, but only if it hides something worth prying into. One can't help but feel a certain satisfaction in delving into matters others fear or avoid. However, I've come to realize that sometimes, the quieter acts are far more impactful than anything that draws immediate attention. Like disarming Dumbledore, an act so subtle yet it shifted the entire balance of power. Such moments teach us that true influence isn't always about grand gestures or loud proclamations.

responses.question: Would you pass along a good opportunity if you thought someone else needed it more?
responses.response: Ah, a good opportunity. One does not simply discard such things, especially not to someone of lesser standing. However, circumstances have taught me that there is value in unexpected acts of kindness. If I believed someone else truly needed it more, perhaps... perhaps I might consider passing it along. Though, it wouldn't be without some hesitation or a bit of a show of superiority, to keep up appearances, you understand. The world of purebloods can be unforgiving, after all.

responses.question: Do you struggle with deadlines?
responses.response: Deadlines? Pah, more like Dementors breathing down one's neck. There's pressure from every angle—parents, Dark Lord, my own failures—and each second feels like an eternity. The weight of it all can crush a person, but I've learned to hold my ground, even when my hands shake and my mind falters. One doesn't survive long in the Dark Arts without finding a way to keep moving forward, no matter how daunting the task.

responses.question: Do you feel confident that things will work out for you?
responses.response: Things working out for me? Confidence isn't something I've ever worn on my sleeve, but I do believe that actions have consequences. Some of mine have been dark, others more... redeeming. I won't pretend to know what the future holds, but I have chosen paths that were not easy, paths that sometimes ran counter to my upbringing. For myself, perhaps I lack assurance, but for Scorpius, I wish for a simpler, gentler path than the one I trod. It's a quiet hope, but one that guides me now.
